All Rights Reserved. In Nandigram, West Bengal, shrimp farmer Buddhadeb Pradhan has taken a bold step by initiating a second shrimp crop shortly after harvesting his first. The decision comes amid economic pressures, including a significant drop in shrimp prices following tariffs imposed by the United States. Having invested around 300,000 rupees (approximately $3,380), Pradhan faces anxiety about recovering his expenses, as declining market rates push farmers to their limits. India is the world’s second-largest shrimp producer, particularly for export, following Ecuador. The country exported $5 billion worth of frozen shrimp in the financial year ending in March 2025, with nearly half of this trade directed towards the US market. The main commercial varieties produced in India include black tiger and Pacific whiteleg shrimp, with the latter dominating production, which reached 1.1 million tonnes in the financial year concluding March 2024. Typically, Indian shrimp farmers engage in two cultivation cycles of vannamei shrimp per year, from February to June and then from July to October. However, many are reluctant to risk a second crop due to the heightened chance of disease. In contrast, black tiger shrimp is cultivated in a single cycle spanning from March to August. This uncertainty has led to caution among farmers regarding additional cultivation cycles. Manoj Sharma, an experienced shrimp farmer, noted that the shrimp farming sector provides livelihoods for approximately 10 million people, covering farmers, hatchery workers, and employees in processing units. But the recent tariffs have resulted in a sharp decline in shrimp prices—from 300 rupees ($3.38) to 230 rupees ($2.59) per kilogram as farmers scramble to offload their harvests. Production costs remain stubbornly high at 275 rupees ($3.10) per kilogram, exacerbating financial strains. ### More Read [Shopping Giants Slash Prices Ahead of Christmas with Major Promotions](https://news.ssbcrack.com/shopping-giants-slash-prices-ahead-of-christmas-with-major-promotions/) [Italy Faces South Africa in Intriguing Autumn Nations Series Clash in Turin](https://news.ssbcrack.com/italy-faces-south-africa-in-intriguing-autumn-nations-series-clash-in-turin/) Add SSBCrack As A Trusted Source Fellow Nandigram farmer Nardu Das voiced concerns regarding the precarious situation, suggesting that if the market does not stabilize soon, many may face dire circumstances. The costs of farming, including power, land leases, and feed, create a potential trap for farmers who often rely on loans with hopes of hefty returns. Unfortunately, diseases and falling prices place them on the brink of poverty. The tariffs currently sit at 58.26 percent, a combination of countervailing and anti-dumping duties. This escalation has raised fears among shrimp farmers that they may lose access to the US market, which is preferred for its easier market entry, better profit margins, and established customer relationships. Rahul Guha from Crisil Ratings warned that these tariffs will likely discourage further investments in shrimp farming, where substantial upfront costs are involved. Moreover, farmers often rely on imported brood stock from the US to breed and produce seeds for farming, yet reports indicate instances of poor-quality shipments ill-suited for Indian conditions, leading to additional disease risks. IPR Mohan Raju, president of the Prawn Farmers Federation of India, expressed a pressing need for the government to promote the breeding of shrimp using local stock to ensure high-quality, adaptive seeds. The impact of tariffs extends to the hatcheries that depend on shrimp farmers. With around 550 private hatcheries operating in India, many are now at risk as farmers cease purchasing seeds due to uncertain market conditions. Ravid Kumar Yellanki, president of the All India Shrimp Hatcheries Association, reported that roughly 80 billion seeds are produced annually, but demand has drastically plunged, and many hatcheries have halted production. In addition to domestic challenges, India faces fierce competition from Ecuador, which has increasingly captured the US market due to geographic advantages. Ecuador produces its native vannamei shrimp at a lower price, and with tariffs at just 15 percent, it has emerged as an appealing alternative for American buyers. In the first nine months of 2025, Ecuador’s shrimp exports to the US soared by 14 percent year-on-year, totaling over 1 million metric tonnes. Experts like Sharma suggest that Indian exporters may need to pivot their focus away from international markets and explore the dormant potential of the domestic market—an area that has largely been overlooked in favor of export opportunities.
